750ml Bottle.  Black appearance with a brown creamy head.  Aroma: fudge, Alcohol, chocolate, molasses, coffee and roasted malts.  Flavor: fudge, saltmolasses, chocolate, alcohol, prunes and roasted malts.  Palate: medium body,  sticky, soft carbonation with a dry finish.

750ml bottle, with thanks to Glouglouburp.  Pours a dark brown/black with a tall foamy tan head.  Nose is overripe dark fruits, chocolate, molasses, and espresso; a bit decadent which is nice.  Flavor is more chocolate, espresso, and dark fruits with an enjoyable underlying roast.  Ive been looking forward to this for a long time, and it did not disappoint.  Thanks again Dany!

Black colored beer that pours nice. Brown edges with a lasting light tan head. Aromas showcases an array of complex dark malt notes. Flavor is very nice, with hints of sour fruit, chocolate, coffee and truffle. Lasting finish is also impressive. Very nice beer.

Acheté au jovi en format de 750ml et brassé à 10% par les trois mousquetaire à lautomne 2008. Dégusté dans un verre trappiste de chimay. Apparence noir extrêmement noir sans effervescence avec une belle mousse brune qui colle à la parois. Odeur de chocolat, de fumé, de raisin, de date, de canneberge avec une touche de vanille et de mélasse sans oublier le sirop dérable. Un goût équilibré de chocolat, de caramel, de vanille, de fruits mûres et de mélasse. Le goût est absolument incroyable, une plénitude wow!

Big, thick, and heavy, luxuriously rich chocolate aroma with underlying fruitiness that evokes blackberries and raisins.  Opaque black body is topped by a dense, strong brown head that lasts well and leaves some lacing on the glass.  Pleasantly complex flavour starts out sweet and chocolatey with notes of vanilla, biscuit, raisins, berries and roasted malts that blens together quite nicely.  Bitterness is pronounced but this is balanced towards the malty sweetness.  Interesting interplay of roasted and fruity flavours in the aftertaste.  Medium full body is a touch syrupy but never sticky.  Moderate carbonation engages the tongue.  Tulip glass.  Cellar temperature.  Bottle purchased at Rahman in Jun-08.
Black with mohagany highlights and a decent sized tan head. Aroma is heavy in chocolate with coffee and roasted malts. Taste is of coffee and dark chocolate. Medium body with some alchol warmth.

[Bottle] Pours a deep black with a fine tan head of bubbles. Fairly thick aroma of caramel sweetness, some vanilla, lager yeast, alcohol, and a touch of smokiness. Flavor is very roasty, which is interesting because it was more or less missing in the aroma, some smoke, chocolate, med-rich mouthfeel, a lot of anise/black licorice, and a bitterish, roasty finish.

Bottle, 10%. Dry roasted aroma, not too interesting. Almost totally black colour, small brown head. The flavour is quite sweet, has some American grassy hops. Some sweet liquorice. The alcohol is not very apparent in the flavour, but it helps to balance the sweetness.
Bottle. Light sour roast nose, coffee. Pitch black, golden brown head. Molassis, roast, some plums, coffee roast, light dryness. Medium body, chewy, light sparkly. Chocolate retronasal.  Nice.

(bottle, thanks MatSciGuy!) Pours dark brown with a tan head that lingers.  Really good aroma of light smoke, berry skin, and roasted malt.  The taste is predominately chocolate, light roasted coffee, cherry skin, that rounds out to a very smooth roasted malt and cocoa finish.  Medium mouthfeel with smooth carbonation.

C&C 750ml. Silky chocolate woven with the faintest hint of smoke on the nose. Anise, darker fruits and cocoa powder all with a hint of sourness. Pours a dark, opaque brown with a thin film of gray. Lots of black liquorice and anise initially on the tongue. Dark, tannic fruit skin. The smoke on the nose is lost on the tongue. A bit of tart acidity on the finish. Rather lush and silky on the tongue with smooth carbonation. Thanks Levi!

750 ml bottle, i think a 2007.  Ebony with a smooth tan head.  Nose is cocoa, prunes and coffee.  Smooth and rich with tongue buzzing carb.  Taste is dark roast and chocolate pudding.  Hints of licorice and sassafras.   Yummy.

Darkest pour with lots of nice head.  Roasted malty aromas with sweet dark fruit and chocolate.  More roasted and burnt malt flavors.  Dark, dried fruit and some dustiness on the finish.  Excellent Porter.

Edition 2008 a 10%. Cremeuse a souhait. Fruits foncer, chocolat, cafe, rotie, alcool sont les saveurs qui dominent. Beau collet qui dure quand meme longtemps pour une biere a 10%. J en fait ager une quelques annees.

10% 2008 edtion. very creamy. Dark fruits, chocolate, coffee and alcohol dominate. Average head that lasts for quite long for a 10% abv beer. I have one aging for a couple of years...

2007 bottle with a different label (bistro l*autre oeil) from glouglouburp.

pours a reddish brown shade of opaque black topped by a medium sized orange tinted cafe au lait colored head. slight horizontal trails of lacing. 

big time tar/asphalt aroma followed by fudgey chocolate, nice tobacco, vanilla, licorice, scalded cream, bruised red apples, fresh strawberries (yep), umami and a slight acidity. 

fairly sweet palate though less than the majority of baltics. it*s cut nicely by a bitterness and great sourness. flavors of chocolate, toasty grain, black raisins, brown sugar, five spice spiciness and black licorice with an ashy charred finish. coffee joins the aftertaste party. medium body. super slick texture. prickly carbonation and char make the sugar almost a non issue and make it a whole bunch easier to drink in quantity.
8/4/8/4/16/4.0

bomber bottle courtesy of fordest. Pours a dark black with a full tan head. The aroma is moderate with molasses and chocolate. The flavor shows lots of rich chocolate along with coffee, mocha and brown sugar. The mouthfeel is smooth and creamy. Overall: A very robust and flavourful Baltic Porter, one I would like to try again sometime.

Bouteille 750ml. De couleur noire et opaque. Nez de malt rôti, de chocolat noir, léger de houblon herbeux et de crème (faibles notes lactiques) avec des notes fruitées (raisins, traces de cerises noires), d’alcool et de fumée de bois. Moyennement ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et une texture riche et moyennement crémeuse. Moyen goût fruité (raisins, notes de cerises noires, traces de prunes) accompagné d’un léger goût de réglisse noire ainsi que d’un léger goût de crème (légèrement lactique) lors de l’entrée en bouche auquel se rajoute rapidement un goût de malt rôti-brûlé ainsi qu’un goût de chocolat noir riche et sucré ainsi que des traces de mélasse et de caramel. Parallèlement, l’on retrouve un léger goût d’alcool réchauffant accompagné d’un léger-moyen gooût de houblon herbeux jusqu’en finale, où l’on dénote également un léger goût boisé.  Post-goût moyen, moyennement amer de rôti-brûlé, de chocolat noir, léger de houblon herbeux, de fruits (moût de raisins et de cerises), d’alcool avec des traces boisées.

750 ml bottle labeled as Porter Baltique poured a clear dark brown with a small lingering brown head. Aromas of smoke, dark chocolate, raisins and light molasses. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of smoke, bakers cocoa, dark fruit and roasted malt with a smooth dry lingering malty finish.

750ml bottle from Glouglouburp. Pours black with a medium sized, slightly fizzy, light brown head. Specks of lace. Smells very roasty malty, slightly smokey with a hint of sweet and a hint of sour malt. Tastes roasty malty, sweet malty and sour malty. Lingering smokiness and sweetness. Medium body, fizzy carbonation.

Bottle 2008..
Aroma:good rosted malt aroma,light chocolate...
Appearance:Dark black good lacing beige head...
Flavor:Good rosted malt,light chocolate...

Via trade with glougoburp.  Pours big and black with 3 fingers of a light brown tan foamy goodness.  The nose is sweet and chocolaty with big roasty malts.  Taste is sweet and chocolaty this is excellent, its very big and very malty, with a lot of bitterness.  This is exactly what a Baltic porter should be huge in a lot of ways and yet slightly restrained as to not be so boozy.

750 courtesy of Glouglouburp.  Pours dark brown with a thin off white head.  Smells of roasted malt, a touch of cherries, burned molasses, some dark licorice.  Tastes sweet and malty with some nice chocolatey hints and some tartness on the finish.
Thanks to bitbucket tasting. Mild coffee. Really smooth.  A little soy and black licorice. Nice roast. Manages to be both rich and smooth at this ABV; well done.

750 ml bottle @ liquid sunshine tasting - thanks to after4ever for this gem; easily one of my favs from the night; dark brown, flat tan head; aromas of rich chocolate; smooth, roasty and rich, nothing off putting in any way as many baltics can be in that stale sense; thick, rich body; tons of chocolate; wow, just a kick ass baltic a not like any i’ve had before except for perhaps the one from cascade; very rich and just a delight; thanks tom!!

Name: E.L. Baltic Porter 1870
Date: 06/20/2008
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting, Cellar Party

Appearance: dark brown, fine tan head, bits of drippy lace, 
Aroma: rich dark chocolate aroma with a touch of dark caramel sweetness, warming brings a dry roastedness, 
Flavor: rich chocolate flavor, caramel sweetness pulls in more of the rich chocolate and gives it a milky sweetness, touch of fruity character,  light balancing bitterness, chocolate and fruit grow to become the dominant profile, 

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 15/20
Rating: 3.7/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: **4

[1363-20080517] 750mL bottle. Boozy coffee roast malt earth aroma with a fruity figgy "bold" base. Dark dark brown body with red highlights and a quick creamy light yellow tan head. Big fruity dark roast flavour has lots of heavy malt. Full body is sweet. Very roasty.
(c/o blankboy, w/ others)

750, corked and baled. Thanks, after4ever!  Pours murky dark brown. with a scant tan head. Soft chocolaty brown sugary nose. Medium body and moderate carbonation. Full sweet chocolate taste with just a hint of smoke. Dry dark chocolate finish.

750, corked and baled. Thanks, Glouglouburp! Pours black with ebony highlights at the edges. Thick creamy medium tan head. Nice chocolatey nose. Big roast under the chocolate. Thick creamy body. Roasty, chocolatey mid-palate. Long roasty sweet finish. Pretty damn amazing, and far more than the sum of its parts.

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2009 Poured black with a large tan head.  Nice roasty malt aroma with milk chocolate notes.  The flavor was also roasty with some milk chocolate.  There was a light tartness to the flavor though.  Medium bodied.

Bottle Thinkin Bout Thirteen Hours O Drinkin (tew man wrecking crew) This beer rocks! Tar black brew with a small, creamy, khaki-colored head. Great retention. Amazing, complex fragrances of dried plum, burnt caramel, tobacco smoke, molasses and cocoa. Full-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and modest carbonation. Burnt malt and singed caramel provide the foundation for lesser flavors of leather, smoke and chocolate. Reminiscent of De Molens Tsarina and Mikkellers X 2006. So much going on here. Cheers to glouglouburp for providing this treat!

Dark brown-near black in colour, lingering thin tan coloured head, light lacing.  The aroma is rich, burnt, some coffee, lots of chocolate, good sweetness, light smoke.  The flavour is of chocolate ice cream, quite sweet, burnt dark malts, molasses, cocoa.  Sweet mouthfeel, full body, medium/high carbonation.  Finishes quite long, burnt, sweet with lots of chocolate.
Very rich and sweet, quite good.  An excellent beer form this brewery, lived up to my expectations.
750ml bottle from Métro Joannette in Verdun, Quebec.
Opened on January 25, 2008
No date.

Pours a mostly opaque black with dark mahogany edges and a thin lacing, wispy dark tan head.  Aroma of sweet dark caramel with some dark chocolate and lightly smoked character.  Body starts fairly full and dark caramely sweet with some complex smooth smoky chocolate notes before a slightly drier finish.  Nicely balanced and very drinkable.

Pours a beautiful deep brown almost black   with a slight head, and average lacing and slightly under carbonated. Smells of very strong coffee with chocolate and a hint of liquorish.  First taste is surprisingly bitter with coffee dominating and chocolate follows.  Nice smoke finish.

Courtesy hopscotch.  Pours black, with a smallish light brown head.  Smells of some burnt dark chocolate, with a profound dark fruit presence, mixed with some roasty malts.  The flavor is mostly the same, with good roasty chocolate malts coming to fruition on the palate.  The finish is fruitier than it is up front, which leaves a sweet finish and aftertaste.  This is a very well done baltic porter.  Great mouthfeel and flavor.
Thanks to Eben for this one.  Black body, brown head.  Chocolate and licorice aromas.  Flavor is chocolaty, sweet, light dry roasted bitter, has a lactic sourness.

Many thanks to Mike for opening this!  Poured deep brown with a short cap of tight beige head.  The aroma was deep with dry-roasted dark chocolates upfront.. coffee grounds and dark fruit backed it up, leaving a rich, dark, and sexy impression.  The flavor had drier dark chocolate, coffee, and dark fruit at the core.. more cocoa-like sugars on the back with dry coffee bitterness riding out the finish.. enjoyable, but a bit harsh at the finish.  Heavier-bodied and drier on the palate with some rough, raw alcohol on the back.. nice roast to it.  Very good beer.

(750ml bottle) Courtesy of Goldorak. Pours a thin, quick dissipating head atop an opaque deep brown body. Nose of a triple bock - so thick with malt, strong soy with a good cherry elixir in the finish. Great flavour off the top. Mixing of burnt chocolate syrup, coffee grounds and roasted marshmallow. Such a refreshing change from my current West Coast hop kick. Thanks Martin!

Bouteille de 750 ml, avec bouchon de liège, achetée au Métro Joanette (Verdun, QC). Arôme: Odeur de chocolat au lait avec une pointe de café au caramel. Apparence: La couleur est noire opaque. Présence dun mince col beige mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de café et de chocolat avec une pointe de caramel. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture minérale. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Arrière goût chocolaté. (Rating #1722)

Poured from a 750 ml bottle.  Deep, oily, chocolatey black.  Slightly tarry aroma with vanilla, brown sugar and creme brulee like toasty sweetness.  Cinnamon, chocolate, espresso, and a mite of lactic sugars.  Dusty sweetness and distant mineral acridity in the flavor; clean bitterness.  Cookie dough, deep fruitiness somewhat buried; wine-like characters seem spritzy and sharp.  Pears.  Syrupy, hot amaretto richness.  Both warm and cool with a firmly carbonated texture and persistent alcohol touch; full bodied and dense; peppermint and gritty chocolatey sweetness before a drawn out, fragrant perfume finish.  Refined to a degree.  Thanks Dany!

(750ml bottle, thanks stine) Small beige head that completely disappears, atop brown-black body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, chocolate syrup, some roast, smoke.  Taste is medium sweet, smoke, chocolate, some roast, light soy, alcohol.  Medium-full body, sticky, low carbonation.

Courtesy of Stine. Dark brown/black with a medium sized tan head. Sweet chocolate nose with raisins, toffee, some alcohol and roast. The flavor is lightly sweet, very lightly bitter with lots of chocolate, raisins, alcohol, molasses and prunes. Full body is round with moderate carbonation.

750mL bottle, courtesy of Stine.  Thanks, Eben!  Pours a dark, chocolate-brown color; light-tan head with mixed-bubbled lacing.  Solid amounts of milk chocolate, nougat, and caramel in the aroma; creamy, chocolate-forward nose.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: chewy chocolate, roasted malts, nougat and caramel upfront; some citrus acidity coming through, with a touch of warming alcohol (not much, but present); lots of chewiness and reasonably well-attenuated maltiness; solid stuff.  Medium finish, showing lots of chocolate, nougat, and caramel.  Good balance of sweet malts and a dry periphery.

2008-05-17.  Black body with a nice tan head that slowly fades. (3+) Aroma is fairly modest, a good amount of roast is dominant but not bombastic, muted sweet malt and light fruit touches. (7+) Sweet smooth malt base, mild roast hints, very mild fruit blends with sugar notes. Smooth medium palate. (3+) Quite nice. At Rudolfs, shared by Blankboy

Bottle, shared at the May 2008 tasting.  Thanks Paul!  Very dark brown, tan head.  Nose is big cocoa, coffee, milky malt, slight iodine.  Flavor is chocolate, honey, rich malt, cocoa, a hint of hops, alcohol.
Bottle from Glouglouburp. Big, bitter, chocolate and burnt espresso aroma. Flavor start very chocolately, milky in the middle, with a very lactic-sweet finish. A great beer.
Bottle. Thanks to Puzzl for sharing this baltic porter.  Pours dark brown with off white head.  Taste/aroma is coco, raisin, smoke, and some etoh.  A good beer.
Bottle, shared by puzzl.  Dark brown, clearish.  Aroma is smoked, some meat and vanilla.  Flavor is the same, some roasted chocolate, smoked and a tiny bit meaty.  Good balance.

25 oz bottle, via jimbowood.  Pours a dark brown body with just the slightest bit of light passing thru.  Nice creamy foamy brown head that retained as a thin film.  Huge intense fruity nose, all plum and to a lesser extent raisons, licorice, and cocoa powder.  Just a touch of roast and some coffee.  Heavy fruit flavor up front starts things off right, but the finish doesnt do it for me.  Seems kinda husky and rough with too much alcohol apparency.  Lingering cocoa nibs and alcohol.  Mouthfeel is full and thick with some lingering sticky clinginess on the finish.  Nice pleasant soft carbonation.  Overall, a little too much of a yeast profile as well.  Ok, but its not as smooth as it could be.  It really comes across as more "ale-y" than "lager-y"  in its character.
Very tasty Baltic.  Nose seems very licorice-like, and the flavor follows suit, a good quality, pure licorice.

750 ml. bottle The color is dark brown with a beige head. The aroma is of malt, the taste is also of malt with added taste of caramel  and dark chocolat. There is a nice bitter finish to it that makes it pleasant.

Bouteille brune de 750 ml. Arômes de grains torréfiés et de cacao. Robe noire et peu effervescente. Goût de torréfaction, de chocolat et présentant une légère touche de fruits rouges. Arrière-goût de torréfaction et dalcool. Lalcool demeure bien dissimulé. Intéressant.

(Dégusté avec french tickler) Biere noire, collet mince brumeux. Odeur pas trés sortant, chocolat, grain de café et une petite senteur sucré. Biere tres crémeuse avec un gout chocolaté et sucré. Vraiment agréable en bouche. Vive le bistro Lautre oeil!!
Black in color with a big thick tan head.  Smells of licorice,  a lot of coffee.  Taste is of roastiness, alcohol, and licorice.  Nice beer.

750  mL bottle received via trade with Glouglouburp.  Pours opaque with an average, fizzy, light brown head, lasting with fair lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (dark chocolate, coffee, toast), light hops (grass), average yeast (leather) with notes of charcoal, prunes, and dates.  Full bodied, creamy texture, average carbonation, and a bitter finish.  Average duration, moderate sweetness, acidity, and bitterness.

(750ml bottle)  Pours a black body with dark brown edges and a small beige head.  Aroma of roastiness, chocolate, black currants, and prunes.  Flavor of roasted (somewhat charred) malt, light black licorice, chocolate, and dark fruit.

Blown away that I got to try this one, damn.  Poured a deep, almost completely black color, the slightest gleaning of brown peeks through the edges.  The aroma is a melange of roasted coffee, dried plums and figs, cocoa and even a slight wisp of smoke.  The flavor is equally as impressive, with an additional acidic note that is the perfect foil to this beer. Simply one of the best Baltic porters I havetasted yet.

Deep black in colour with a nice tan-coloured head. Aroma is malt, chocolate and coffee with a tinge of fruitiness. Nice body with a roasted coffee flavour that is followed by a bit of sugar. Alcohol is quite well hidden, but adds a tiny touch of warmth.  Excellent brew.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2010 Bière enivrante, pesante, qui réchauffe par une froide soirée dhiver. Notes de chocolat sucré, bonne rondeur maltée. Superbe bière qui na pas grand chose à envier aux grosses bières noires de la baltique... Elle serait tout simplement sublime avec une maturation de quelques mois en fûts de chêne. Un jour, peut-être...

Roasted malt flavor lets itself be known right away in the aroma.  Pours a nice coffee color with a thick tan head tha disappears quickly.  The first few sips of this beer were excellent.  The roasted maltt and chocolate came to the front and some more subtle almost berry characteristics were at the back, but after half a glass it was all roasted malt and got a little bitter.  Maybe its just the style of beer.  Good stuff though.

Draught at Le Saint-Bock, Montreal. Deep brown with a small tan head. Strong aroma of deep roasted malt, chocolate, dark fruit. Soft, creamy mouthfeel - none of the sticky, syrupy character often found in Baltics. Full-flavoured, sweet and roasty, with notes of coffee, charred malt, and freshly baked dark chocolate chip cookies. Drinks more like a 6% beer than a 9.8%. Excellent!

Bouteille 750 ml. Couleur noir avec de petits reflets rougeâtres. Mousse , beau collet qui tient. Au nez des arômes de chocolat-caramel-vanille-café-alcool se font persuasif et non discret. En Bouche la bière est assez ronde et nous fais découvrir des saveurs de chocolat noir, de café, de caramel sucré, de vanille et dalcool. WOW  je suis vraiment surpris de cette bière la.

Bouteille de 750 ml, acheté le 19/12/07 chez Peluso (Montréal), bu ce soir. Brune rougeatre très foncée, petit collet beige que persiste. Arome de cacao cafiné doucement roti et de pain grillé avec un peu de Nutella. Gout de malte chocolaté roti, café sec en un peu amère, doucement sucré, lalcool nest pas trop présant. Une vrai délice!

The pour reveals a pitch black color with a thick tan head. Strong and pleasant aroma of chocolate, roasted malt and toasted bread. Very good flavor of chocolate, vanila, roasted and smoked malt and toasted bread with a bitter finish. The body is medium with a liquorous texture and moderate carbonation.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2008 In short: Ultra-dry cacaolized roasted porter.  Very good.
How: Bottle 750ml (one bottle on first week of release and another bottle 2 months old)
The look: Black body with a short-lived tan head
In long: When first released the brew felt very roasted and syrupy.  A few months later the roastiness level is medium and the beer has dried out a lot.  Powdery and dry cacao sensation.  Burnt toasts with Nutella.  Light fruity notes of prunes and blackberries.  Body is round and smooth despite the overall dryness.  Notes of charcoal.  Mouth drying finish.  Lively carbonation.  No alcohol presence at all.  Very good brew although not quite the sweet/syrupy taste Ive come to expect from Baltic Porters.  Quite original in fact.  The one-batch Signature brews from Trois Mousquetaires truly are excellent but when drinking them Im also sad to think that they might not be brewed again.  Because of that they bring me both great pleasure and sadness like watching a beautiful 18th century historical building burn down with the KKK leaders still trapped inside for their annual meeting.

On tap at lAutre Oeil (Gatineau, Qc). Pours a blacj opaque body with a thin but lasting beige foamy head. Good malty aroma with coffeeish hints. Alcohol is very well hidden. Nice, complex taste that darries roasted coffee, black chocolate and brown sugar notes. Ends with a robust bitter/roasty finish. Well done!

750ml bottle brewed for LAutre Oeil, dark pitch black color, with a tan-colored head, but falls quickly, roasty, black malt nose, with some burnt toast and black coffee bean notes, with a faint vanilla, mochaish-espresso accent, with a black chocolatey a subtle fruity aroma with a full-bodied palate with a sweet fruity, toasty, roasted black malt character, with a dark bitter-chocolatey note, with some vanilla, mocha, burnt coffee bean accents, with a faint plummy, datey, juicy flavor, with warmth mouthfeel, leading towards a warming, fruity, dry roastiness finish.

My bottle (750ml) shared with HogTownHarry & tupalev. Pours black with a large lasting foamy beige head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, dark fruit, egg-shells and some grassy hops. Delicious flavour of roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, dark fruit and hops. Dry, roasted finish. Alcohols well hidden. Medium to full bodied, creamy mouthfeel. Holy crap this is great,  Les Trois Mousquetaires continue to impress.

750ml bottle from the Festivus Guy, and shared with Mike.  Opaque black, with brown head.  Spotty lace.  Nose of cooling tar, used coffee grounds, a little gassy-ness, and some herbal hops.  Flavors of char, chocolate covered coffee beans, a touch of vanilla, and a raisin finish.  Pretty thin.  Light body.  Semi sweet.  Not a favorite of the style.

750 mL bottle as "Bistro LAutre Oeil BP" from Jovi, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass.
App.:  Deep, dark brown-black with a moderate light mocha head.
  
Aroma:  An interesting blend of fruit (grapes, berries and cherries), chocolate, black coffee, alcohol, wood, and light funk; a bit of vanilla and caramel, a little smoke; it changes a bit with each sniff.
  
Palate:  Thick, slick body and soft carbonation.
  
Flav.:  Fruits, wood and alcohol, very little coffee or chocolate initially, a vegetal note, nutty; an interesting contrast to the nose; just a hint of tang, some sweetness, a touch of bitterness; a bit of warming alcohol lingers with a nutty finish.

Interesting, enigmatic and complex.  The alcohol is hidden well, perhaps too well.  This could be dangerous.

750ml caged and corked bottle and brought to our little tasting by Tom, much thanks! Nearly opaque with a long lasting beige head and okay lacing. he aroma has notes of plum, prune, pipe tobacco, aromatic and grassy hops, walnut, mineral water, star anise and yes WINTERGREEN (dont ask me how). I wonderful phenolic nose leads me towards the first taste. Starts malty and fruity as expected with a nice sharp bitterness in support. Hints of bakers chocolate and walnut before rambling off to the lightly spiced and earthy finish. The mouth feel is sharp and aggressive with a warming finish, nice clean dry finish. I dug this more than Tom it seems, even if it is more aggressive than normally found for the genre. MIKEY LIKEY, try some you.

Bottle shared with Hogtown Harry and Blankboy, Blankboys bottle.  Pitch black, big bubbly tan head, Im not sure how it could look any better!  Really nice aroma - strong sweet roast.  Rich full body.  Great taste - rich roast, lots of chocolate, lots of alcohol.  Thick silky body.  This is dead on style wise - great stuff, well done Trois Mousquetaires!

Bottle (750ml - corked & caged).  Shared with blankboy and tupalev, blankboys bottle.  Basically black pour, large fluffy-creamy beige head.  Wonderful dry deep roast aroma, light cream and floral hops, hint of tart fruit.  Taste follows, more fruit tartness and increasing alcohol - plus coffee.  Fairly light, slick body, light acidity and alcohol - long slick, roasty-tart finish.  Im no style expert, but Im thinking this is bang-on.  Regardless, great stuff.

Courtesy of Glouglouburp. Pours a dark black with slight tan head. Has hints of roasted malts, caramel, vanilla, huge coffee aroma and taste. Finishes with a thick roasted taste on the tongue. Very good brew.

Drank the Les Trois Mousquetaires Lautre il Porter Baltique version, brown bottle, 750 ml, purchased at La Trappe à Fromage, savoured on the last day of 2007; eye: black, opaque, a nice creamy beige head, a bit of lacing; nose: roasted malt, roasting, light vanilla, caramel, dark chocolate; mouth: lots of roasting but despite that quite smooth almost velvety, light acridness present throughout each sip, a bit of caramel, hops appears close to the finale, finale is drier than expected as a result of the hops coming out, roasted finale with a hint of caramel that arrives to balance everything, mildly sweet and bitter, medium to full body, slightly oily texture, not much carbonation, light astringency; overall: quite good

FRANÇAIS

Bue la version Les Trois Mousquetaires Lautre il Porter Baltique, bouteille brune, 750 ml, achetée à La Trappe à Fromage, savourée le 31 décembre 2007; il : noire, opaque, un beau collet de mousse crémeuse beige, un peu de dentelle; nez : malt torréfié, torréfaction, léger vanille, caramel, chocolat noir; bouche : très torréfaction mais malgré cela, très douce même veloutée, légère âcreté présente tout au long de la gorgée, un peu de caramel, amertume apparaît vers la finale, finale en torréfaction où une pointe de caramel vient balancer le tout, finale plus sèche que prévue suite à lapparition du houblon, moyennement sucrée et houblonnée, corps moyen à corsé, texture légèrement huileuse, peu carbonatée, légère astringence; en résumé : très bonne

750ml bottle from Glouglouburp. thanks! First US rate! pours dark brown with small almost non-existent tan head. nose of coffee and dark fruits. flavor is nutty, coffee, chocolate, and dark fruits with a smooth clean dry finish. the finish is just a touch too dry. carbonation is a tad fizzy. a really nice baltic porter.

Bottle @ Lautre Oeil - Picth black poor with light brown head and obvious effervescence.  Aromas of creamy dark chocolate, malty (caramelised), alcohol, caramel, moca coffee and thym.  Creamy palate, velvety, good effervescence and full bodied.  Long lasting bitterness and flavors.  Flavors are farely the same as the aromas... Impressive overall!

My Bottom Line:
Sensuous dark chocolate harbors a few dried blackberries, a regal entity morphing into roasting molasses in the last half of each sip. This is a Baltic Porter of the utmost wealth and elegance.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A creamy sheet of foam slowly dissolves into a ring atop the jet black.
-The fruitiness is always contained within the chocolate and molasses sweetness, yet still develops notes of prunes, dates and raisins.
-Amazingly enough, there is no alcohol presence in the flavor profile.
-The flavors are seamlessly integrated into one another; this is cohesion at its best.
-Carbonation is beautifully pillowy, but Ive heard the bottled versions are livelier. Ive yet to sample it from the bottle, so a re-rate will come shortly.
-The closest relative to this Baltic Porter I can find is Thomas Hookers Imperial Porter. Both sumptuous homages to the malt.
-This has been a superb year for Trois Mousquetaires on the craft beer front. Heres to many more!

On tap at Vices et Versa.

Bottle: Poured a pitch-black color ale with a medium size foamy head with average retention and minimal lacing. Aroma consists of light black chocolate with some sweetness coming through. Taste is a mix between some black chocolate malt with a seriously dry ending. Full body with medium carbonation and no alcohol was apparent with some vinous notes without being cloying. I am not exactly sure what to make of this beer  different and not totally on style but still interesting nonetheless.

Almost black, clear around the edges beer with a healthy tan head. A very strong, considerably attenuated dark beer which has a fair bit in common with their Porthos (doppelbock). Switch the toastiness to roastiness, add a pinch of alcohol and youre quite there - the general relation between doppelbocks and baltic porter. By using the same yeast strain, we get similar alcohol connotations, although there may be a further vinous feel here. Were dealing with both blackberry-like fruitiness and a couple of dark grapes. Not quite juicy though as the lager yeast has done a remarkable attenuating job. The carbonation is therefore quite lively for a beer of this type and the associated alcohol feels warming, but never serves as a focus point flavour-wise. Obviously, a fair bit of roastiness is constantly present. I cant really box it into a coffee reminding or chocolate reminding mold, more like plain borderline burnt toast. Thankfully, the fruit notes are devoid of inherent acidity, thus avoiding any clash or astringency. Obviously spot on what they were aiming at. Solid all around. Light-medium body has obviously lost a fair bit of thickness through the yeasts enthusiasm. Seriously, this is much drier than Id have expected. Certainly not a typical vinous, slightly tart, fruity and rather sweet baltic porter with bold contrasting chocolate notes. More of a roasty doppelbock whose yeast went beyond the call of duty. Now to determine if I like it more than the Porthos... Im afraid I might be alone in that camp, but I think not. Both are really worth trying, but afterwards, between the very good one, quite available, at a retail price 4.99$ and the very good one, very rare indeed, at 7.99$, Ill stick with the Porthos.

bière totalement noire non-translucide, mousse brunâtre compacte, beaucoup deffervescence. nez de torréfaction prononcé, la bouche est légère malgré lalcool, on ne la sent pas du tout, goût torréfié, agréable.
